choices.text: Hyperactivity and impulsivity
Intellectual disability
Hypersensitivity to sensory input
Rapid language acquisition

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his delayed speech development and lack of social interactions. She reports that he does not respond when his name is called, avoids making eye contact, and prefers to play alone. The child has a particular interest in lining up his toy cars and becomes extremely upset with any change in routine. His play is repetitive, and he shows little interest in playing with other children. On examination, the pediatrician notes that the child does not follow pointing gestures and does not point at objects to show interest. Based on the clinical presentation, the pediatrician suspects autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Which of the following is a common clinical feature of ASD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypersensitivity to sensory input

 

Option C:

 

Hypersensitivity to sensory input is a common feature in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Many children with ASD have unusual responses to sensory stimuli. This can manifest as hypersensitivity (over-responsiveness) or hyposensitivity (under-responsiveness) to sensory inputs like sounds, lights, textures, or smells. This sensory processing issue can contribute to behaviors such as avoiding loud environments, disliking being touched, or being fascinated by certain visual stimuli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyperactivity and impulsivity - These symptoms are more characteristic of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) than ASD. Although some children with ASD can display hyperactivity and impulsivity, these are not core features of ASD.

 

Option B. Intellectual disability - While some individuals with ASD may also have intellectual disability, it is not a defining characteristic of ASD. Intellectual abilities in individuals with ASD can range from superior to severely challenged.

 

Option D. Rapid language acquisition - This is not typically associated with ASD. In fact, individuals with ASD often experience delays in language development, and some may not develop significant spoken language.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASD is characterized by challenges in social communication, repetitive behaviors, and in some cases, unusual responses to sensory stimuli, such as hypersensitivity or hyposensitivity. Recognizing these features is crucial for early diagnosis and intervention, which can significantly improve outcomes for children with ASD.

 

Ref: O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 56.

choices.text: Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication
Arrange for special education placement
Send the child for a complete psychoeducational assessment
Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother due to concerns about his performance in school. His teachers report that he often seems to be "in his own world" during class, frequently fails to complete assignments, and is easily distracted by minor noises or movements in the classroom. At home, his mother notes that he forgets to do his chores, has difficulty organizing his tasks, and loses his school supplies regularly. During the evaluation, the boy frequently interrupts the conversation, fidgets in his seat, and struggles to wait his turn to speak. After a thorough evaluation, it is determined that the boy meets 7 of the 9 criteria for inattention according to the DSM-5 guidelines and displays several impulsive behaviors. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Send the child for a complete psychoeducational assessment

 

Option C:

 

A complete psychoeducational assessment is the most appropriate next step in the management of a child suspected of having Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) after initial evaluation suggests significant inattention and impulsivity. This comprehensive assessment includes cognitive testing, academic achievement testing, and evaluations for learning disorders, which can coexist with ADHD. It helps to understand the child's learning style, strengths, and weaknesses, and is essential for formulating an effective treatment plan, which may include educational interventions, behavioral strategies, and possibly medication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication - While stimulant medications are a cornerstone in the treatment of ADHD, initiating treatment should ideally follow a thorough assessment, including a psychoeducational evaluation, especially in complex cases or when comorbidities are suspected.

 

Option B. Arrange for special education placement - Special education placement may be part of the management for a child with ADHD, but it should be based on a comprehensive assessment of the child's educational needs and not as an initial step without a complete evaluation.

 

Option D. Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate - This option is inappropriate because the described behaviors significantly impair the child's functioning in multiple settings, suggesting that they are beyond typical age-appropriate behavior.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management steps after an initial ADHD evaluation suggests a comprehensive psychoeducational assessment for confirming the diagnosis, and to rule out other conditions, understand the child's unique needs, and guiding the management plan, which may include educational adjustments, behavioral strategies, and medication.

 

Ref: O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 56.

choices.text: Delayed language development
Hyperactivity and impulsivity
Abnormalities in facial features
Progressive loss of motor skills

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's developmental progress. The mother reports that her daughter began walking at 18 months, later than most children, and has recently started to lose the ability to use her hands effectively; she often wrings her hands together and has difficulty grasping toys. The child was noted to have microcephaly at her 12-month check-up, and her growth has remained below the 3rd percentile for her age. The pediatrician also notes a history of feeding difficulties, including poor suck and swallow coordination. Given the history of normal early development followed by regression in motor skills, loss of purposeful hand movements, and the presence of stereotypic movements, the pediatrician suspects Rett’s syndrome. Which of the following is a common clinical feature of Rett’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Progressive loss of motor skills

 

Option D:

 

Rett’s syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder that primarily affects females. It is characterized by normal early growth and development followed by a slowing of development, loss of purposeful use of the hands, distinctive hand movements such as wringing or washing, slowed brain and head growth, problems with walking, and seizures. The progressive loss of motor skills and the development of stereotypic hand movements are hallmark features of this condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Delayed language development - While children with Rett’s syndrome may experience delays in language and communication skills, the most distinctive feature of the disorder is the regression in motor skills and the development of stereotypic hand movements.

 

Option B. Hyperactivity and impulsivity - These are not hallmark features of Rett’s syndrome and are more commonly associated with other disorders such as ADHD.

 

Option C. Abnormalities in facial features - While some genetic syndromes are characterized by distinct facial features, Rett’s syndrome is not typically associated with specific abnormalities in facial features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rett’s syndrome, is a rare genetic neurological and developmental disorder that affects the way the brain develops, resulting in a progressive loss of motor skills and language. Recognizing the pattern of normal development (for the first 6-18 months) followed by regression in motor skills and the presence of stereotypic hand movements is the key to suspecting and diagnosing Rett’s syndrome.

 

Ref: O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 60

choices.text: Conduct disorder
ADHD
Dyslexia
Autism spectrum disorder

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is referred to a psychiatric clinic by his school due to concerns about his behavior. Teachers and his parents report a pattern of aggressive outbursts, physical fights, and deliberate destruction of property. The boy has been caught stealing from classmates and lying about his actions on multiple occasions. His academic performance has declined over the past year, and he has been suspended several times for vandalism and fighting. The boy shows little remorse for his actions and tends to blame others for provoking him. His past medical history is unremarkable, and there is no evidence of a significant learning disorder or intellectual disability. Based on the boy's history of aggressive behavior, violation of social norms, and lack of empathy, the psychiatrist suspects a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by these features. Which of the following is a common clinical feature of the suspected disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conduct disorder

 

Option A:

 

Conduct disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder diagnosed in childhood or adolescence that presents with a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior in which the basic rights of others or major age-appropriate societal norms or rules are violated. These behaviors include aggressive conduct that causes or threatens physical harm to other people or animals, non-aggressive conduct that causes property loss or damage, deceitfulness or theft, and serious violations of rules. The lack of empathy and remorse, alongside aggressive behavior and a history of violating others' rights, are hallmark features of conduct disorder.

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. ADHD: Inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity are core features of ADHD, along with potential difficulties in executive functions. ADHD does not inherently include aggressive or antisocial behaviors as defining features.

 

Option C. Dyslexia: This learning disorder is characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities, not by aggressive or antisocial behavior.

 

Option D. Autism spectrum disorder: ASD is characterized by difficulties in social communication and repetitive behaviors, but it does not typically include aggressive or antisocial behaviors as defining features unless in response to sensory overload or extreme stress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conduct disorder, a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior that violates the rights of others or major societal norms. Recognizing the clinical features of conduct disorder is crucial for early intervention and management, which may include behavioral therapy and family counseling.

 

Ref: O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 56

choices.text: Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication
Obtain further information from the parents and teachers
Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate
Send the child for psychological assessment

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient pediatric department by his mother, who expresses concerns that her son might have Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). She describes him as being extremely restless at home, having a persistent inability to focus on tasks, and frequently misplacing his belongings. Despite these concerns, the child appears cooperative during the visit and his physical examination does not reveal any abnormalities. The mother is eager for advice on how to manage her son's symptoms and improve his ability to concentrate and remain organized. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obtain further information from the parents and teachers.

 

Option B:


When ADHD is suspected, it is critical to gather comprehensive information from multiple sources, including parents, teachers, and other caregivers, to understand the child's behavior in different settings. ADHD symptoms must be present in more than one setting (e.g., both at home and school) to meet diagnostic criteria. This information can be collected using standardized rating scales and questionnaires that assess the child's behavior, attention span, and impulsivity across various environments. This approach helps to ensure a thorough evaluation and accurate diagnosis before considering treatment options.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication - Starting medication without a thorough assessment and definitive diagnosis is inappropriate. Stimulant medications are a mainstay in the treatment of ADHD but should only be considered after a comprehensive evaluation confirms the diagnosis.

 

Option C. Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate - While some level of inattention and restlessness can be normal for children, the mother's concerns and the description of the child's behavior warrant a thorough evaluation to rule out ADHD or other disorders.

 

Option D. Send the child for psychological assessment - While a psychological assessment may be part of the evaluation process for ADHD, the initial step should involve gathering detailed information from those who observe the child in various settings. If the initial information supports the possibility of ADHD, a more in-depth psychological assessment might then be warranted.

 

Educational Objective:


The initial approach to evaluate a child suspected of having ADHD - Comprehensive evaluation including obtaining a detailed information from parents and teachers, is essential before considering a diagnosis of ADHD and discussing treatment options. This ensures that any intervention is based on a thorough understanding of the child's behaviors across different environments.

 

Ref: O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 56-59

choices.text: Impaired coordination and balance
Hyperactivity and impulsivity
Obsessive-compulsive symptoms
Difficulty with memory and learning

questions.text: A mother brings her 10-year-old child to a neurology clinic concerned about her child's sudden, involuntary movements. She reports that these movements involve the face and limbs and have been occurring for more than a year. Additionally, she mentions that her child occasionally makes unexpected vocal sounds, such as grunts or throat clearing, which seem involuntary. The child's academic performance is good, and there are no concerns regarding cognitive development. However, the repetitive nature of the movements and sounds, along with their involuntary appearance, prompts the neurologist to consider a diagnosis of Tourette's syndrome, a type of tic disorder. Which of the following is a common clinical feature of tic disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obsessive-compulsive symptoms

 

Option C:
 

Tic disorders, including Tourette's syndrome, are characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, nonrhythmic motor movements or vocalizations. One of the common comorbid conditions associated with tic disorders is obsessive-compulsive symptoms or disorder (OCD). Individuals with Tourette's syndrome may exhibit behaviors that resemble OCD, such as compulsions (repetitive behaviors driven by a need to reduce anxiety related to obsessions) and obsessions (persistent, unwanted thoughts, impulses, or images).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Impaired coordination and balance - This is not a defining feature of tic disorders, although some individuals with tic disorders might have motor tics that temporarily disrupt their coordination or balance.

 

Option B. Hyperactivity and impulsivity - While ADHD is a common comorbidity with tic disorders, hyperactivity and impulsivity are not clinical features of tic disorders themselves but rather of ADHD.

 

Option D. Difficulty with memory and learning - Tic disorders do not inherently involve difficulties with memory and learning. Any such difficulties are more likely to be related to comorbid conditions or the social and academic impact of the tics.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Obsessive-compulsive symptoms are common in individuals with tic disorders, especially those with Tourette's syndrome. These symptoms can include repetitive behaviors, intrusive thoughts, and compulsions.

 

Ref: O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 56-59

choices.text: Difficulty with spelling
Impaired motor coordination
Difficulty with math
Rapid language acquisition

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is referred to a psychologist by his school due to persistent academic difficulties, particularly in reading and writing. His teacher reports that despite average intelligence and effort, the child struggles to recognize words, confuses letters that look similar, and has difficulty understanding the sounds letters make. The child's mother adds that he had delayed speech milestones and has always found rhyming games challenging, unlike his peers. The psychologist observes the child's reading session and notes significant difficulty in decoding simple words, which impacts his reading fluency and comprehension. Given the child's history of delayed speech, difficulty with phonological awareness, and specific challenges with reading and writing, dyslexia is suspected. Which of the following is a common clinical feature of dyslexia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Difficulty with spelling

 

Options A:

 

Dyslexia is a specific learning disorder characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities. These difficulties are often due to a deficit in the phonological component of language that is unexpected in relation to other cognitive abilities and the provision of effective classroom instruction. Difficulty with spelling is a common feature of dyslexia, as individuals with this condition often struggle to connect sounds to letter combinations effectively, making spelling a challenging task.

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Impaired motor coordination - While some individuals with dyslexia may experience challenges with motor coordination, it is not a defining feature of dyslexia and is more commonly associated with dyspraxia or developmental coordination disorder.

 

Option C. Difficulty with math - Known as dyscalculia, difficulty with math is a distinct condition from dyslexia, which primarily affects reading and related language-based processing skills.

 

Option D. Rapid language acquisition - This is not associated with dyslexia; in fact, individuals with dyslexia often experience delayed language acquisition, particularly in the areas of speech and phonological awareness.

 

Educational Objective:


Dyslexia, a specific learning disorder that involves difficulty in reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and learning how they relate to letters and words (decoding). Recognizing the signs of dyslexia, such as difficulty with spelling and word recognition, is crucial for early intervention and support, which can significantly improve reading skills and academic performance.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 1446

choices.text: Bipolar disorder
Oppositional-defiant disorder
Pervasive developmental disorder
Posttraumatic stress disorder

questions.text: A 13-year-old adolescent male is brought to a child psychiatrist by his parents due to concerns about his academic performance and behavior both at home and in school. He has been described as frequently distracted, forgetful in daily activities, and often fails to follow through on tasks and schoolwork. The boy also exhibits fidgetiness, has difficulty remaining seated, and often interrupts others. After a comprehensive evaluation, he has been diagnosed with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Given the high comorbidity rates with ADHD, the psychiatrist decides to evaluate the adolescent for coexisting psychiatric disorders to provide a holistic treatment plan. Which of the following psychiatric disorders is the adolescent most likely to have in conjunction with ADHD?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oppositional-defiant disorder

 

Option B:


Oppositional-defiant disorder (ODD) is a frequent comorbid condition with ADHD, characterized by a pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness. Children and adolescents with ADHD are at an increased risk of developing ODD, possibly due to the frustrations associated with the symptoms of ADHD, such as inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity, which can lead to conflicts with authority figures and peers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bipolar disorder - While ADHD can coexist with bipolar disorder, it is less common than ODD in individuals with ADHD. Bipolar disorder involves episodes of mood swings ranging from depressive lows to manic highs, which is different from the behavioral issues seen in ODD.

 

Option C. Pervasive developmental disorder - This category, primarily associated with autism spectrum disorders, represents a different set of developmental issues than those typically seen in ADHD. The core symptoms involve significant challenges in social interaction and communication.

 

Option D. Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) - PTSD can occur in children and adolescents who have experienced or witnessed a traumatic event. While it can coexist with ADHD, it is not as commonly comorbid with ADHD as ODD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common coexisting psychiatric conditions with ADHD, includes:

 

  • Oppositional defiant disorder (35.2%),
  • Conduct disorder (25.7%),
  • Anxiety disorder (25.8%), and
  • Depressive disorder (18.2%).

 

Ref: O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 56-59
